bioghist.p: Charles Dickens (1812-1870) was one of the most popular English novelists of the Victorian era as well as a vigorous social campaigner. Hablot Knight Browne (1815-1882) was an English artist, famous as Phiz, the illustrator of the best-known books by Charles Dickens, Charles Lever and Harrison Ainsworth in their original editions. Dickens met George Cruikshank (1792-1878) through the publisher John Macrone, who suggested that Dickens should put together a book with illustrations by Cruikshank. The result was Sketches by Boz published in 1836. Cruikshank would later illustrate Dickens' Oliver Twist and was an actor in some of the plays done by Dickens' amateur company. George Cattermole (1800-1868), was a Dickens friend and illustrator, collaborating with Browne (Phiz), on Master Humphrey's Clock and the novels The Old Curiosity Shop and Barnaby Rudge. Cattermole's specialty was interior and exterior architectural illustration rather than character drawings.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of original drawings for Dickens by Hablot Knight Browne (Phiz), George Cattermole, and George Cruikshank. The collection contains pencil, charcoal, and several pencil and pen drawings by Browne for David Copperfield, Domby and Son, and Bleak House. The collection also includes pencil sketches by Cruickshank including a study for "Bumble" from Oliver Twist; letters from Kate Perugini, Dickens's daughter, addressed to Mr. Charles Sessler; several issues of The Bookman magazine with presentation plate portraits of Charles Dickens (1910-1912); a set of 12 hand-colored extra illustrations to the Pickwick Papers, by Charles E. Brock, 1921; lithographic portrait of Charles Dickens by H. Blackburn Hart; and two engravings, one by Darley and the other by Cruickshank. The collection also contains greeting cards, Christmas cards, and postcards featuring illustrations from Dickens (1905-1965); and postcards of the Dickens house and other Dickens-related images.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
